skill.description: Implement modern responsive layouts using container queries, fluid typography, CSS Grid, and mobile-first breakpoint strategies. Use when building adaptive interfaces, implementing fluid layouts, or creating component-level responsive behavior.

All static scanner findings are false positives: backticks detected are markdown code fences, URLs are documentation links, and all references to cryptographic or system commands are text mentions within documentation. content.value_statement: Building interfaces that adapt across devices is complex and time-consuming. This skill provides ready-to-use code patterns for container queries, fluid typography, CSS Grid layouts, and mobile-first breakpoints to speed up responsive development.
actual_capabilities: Generate mobile-first media queries for responsive breakpoints
Implement container queries for component-level responsiveness
Create fluid typography scales using CSS clamp()
Build responsive grid layouts with CSS Grid and auto-fit
Develop responsive navigation patterns for mobile and desktop
Implement responsive images with srcset and picture elements
limitations: Does not generate JavaScript for responsive behavior logic
Does not test layouts on actual devices or browsers
Does not provide design mockups or visual assets

prompt_templates.title: Basic container query setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a responsive card component using CSS container queries. The card should switch from stacked to side-by-side layout when the container is at least 400px wide.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a component that responds to its container size

prompt_templates.title: Fluid typography scale
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a fluid typography scale using CSS clamp(). Create variables for text-xs through text-4xl with min sizes around 12px to 18px and max sizes around 14px to 36px.

prompt_templates.title: Responsive grid layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a responsive grid layout using CSS Grid with auto-fit. The grid should have columns that are at least 250px wide and wrap to new rows as needed.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building a responsive gallery or card grid

prompt_templates.title: Mobile-first breakpoint strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Define a mobile-first breakpoint strategy for a design system. Include breakpoints at 640px, 768px, 1024px, and 1280px with typical use cases for each.

output_examples.input: Create a responsive card with container queries

best_practices: Start with mobile styles and enhance for larger screens using min-width media queries
Use container queries for component-level responsiveness instead of viewport-based queries
Set breakpoints based on content needs rather than specific device dimensions
Use relative units like rem, em, and percentages for scalable layouts
anti_patterns: Using fixed pixel widths instead of fluid or relative units
Creating breakpoints for specific device sizes rather than content reflow points
Applying responsive styles at the viewport level when component-level queries would be better
Ignoring dynamic viewport units that account for mobile browser UI

faq.question: What are container queries and how do they differ from media queries?
faq.answer: Container queries apply styles based on the size of a parent container rather than the viewport. Media queries respond to the viewport width. Container queries enable truly reusable components that adapt to their container regardless of where they are placed.

faq.question: How does fluid typography work?
faq.answer: Fluid typography uses CSS clamp() to create font sizes that scale smoothly between minimum and maximum values based on the viewport width. This eliminates the need for multiple breakpoint-specific font sizes.

faq.question: What is the mobile-first approach?
faq.answer: Mobile-first means writing base styles for mobile devices first, then adding enhancements with min-width media queries for larger screens. This approach improves performance on mobile and simplifies the stylesheet structure.

faq.question: When should I use CSS Grid vs Flexbox?
faq.answer: Use CSS Grid for two-dimensional layouts (rows and columns simultaneously). Use Flexbox for one-dimensional layouts (single row or column). Grid excels at page-level layouts; Flexbox works well for component-level alignment.

faq.question: What are dynamic viewport units?
faq.answer: Dynamic viewport units (dvh, svh, lvh) account for mobile browser UI that appears and disappears. Use 100dvh for full height that adjusts to show/hide browser chrome, 100svh for the smallest viewport, and 100lvh for the largest.

faq.question: How do I test responsive designs effectively?
faq.answer: Test on real devices when possible. Use browser DevTools device emulation for initial checks. Focus on common breakpoint ranges rather than specific devices. Test touch targets, text readability, and content overflow at each breakpoint.
